content.text: **Quantificational logic** (also called predicate logic or first-order logic) extends propositional logic by adding the ability to talk about *quantities* of things. Instead of just saying 'P is true', we can now say 'All things have property P' or 'Some things have property P'.

This is a major leap in expressive power. Consider the classic syllogism: 'All humans are mortal. Socrates is human. Therefore, Socrates is mortal.' Propositional logic can't capture the internal structure of 'All humans are mortal' — it would just be a single proposition P. But quantificational logic can express the *generality* of this claim.

content.definition: Read as 'for all' or 'for every'. The statement ∀x(P(x)) means 'for all x, P(x) is true' — in other words, everything has property P.
Read as 'there exists' or 'for some'. The statement ∃x(P(x)) means 'there exists an x such that P(x) is true' — at least one thing has property P.

symbols.name: Universal
symbols.meaning: For all, for every, for each

symbols.name: Existential
symbols.meaning: There exists, for some, at least one

content.question: What does ∀x(P(x)) mean?
options: Exactly one thing has property P
content.explanation: The universal quantifier ∀ means 'for all'. So ∀x(P(x)) says that for every x in our domain, P(x) is true — everything has property P.
